Layers

Layers are among the fundamental features in Photoshop which aid editing. Superficially, they're simple, but the feature set goes deep.
Apps Used:

Topics

  • Day One
  • Drawing with Shapes
  • Pen Tool
  • Setting Type
  • Types of Swatches
  • Gradients & Blends
  • Illustrator Fundamentals
  • Our First Layout
  • VW Layout
  • Raster Image Fundamentals
  • Layers
  • Intro to Layer Masks
  • Retouching Fundamentals
  • Magazine Cover

Watch the Video Tutorial

Photoshop layers are like sheets of stacked acetate. You can see through transparent areas of a layer to the layers below. You move a layer in the Layers panel stacking order to position the content on the layer, like sliding a sheet of acetate in a stack. You can also change the opacity of a layer to make content partially transparent.

The Layers panel is dense with buttons, sliders and other controls. Weâ€™ll explore these in class. Layers can be locked in five different ways, like locking transparency, locking position and more.

Layer organization and stacking order is a whole other area to master. Naming layers is important for your own work and even more for collaboration. This is a must-read if you want to respect industry-standard Photoshop etiquette.

Filter Layers

These buttons are especially useful when you have a large number of layers in your Photoshop file. You can click one of them to see only that type of layer. As an example, you can vew only Adjustment Layers.

This doesnâ€™t turn on/off the visibility on the canvas. It only filters the layers in the panel.

Blend Modes

Blend Modes determine how the pixels on a layer above mix with pixels on the layer below. They can also be used with an individual tool. So, you can brush in a specific blend mode. This is Adobeâ€™s detailed descriptions of each Blend Mode.

Locks

  1. Lock transparent pixels: When you paint, only pixels get painted. Transparency isnâ€™t affected.
  2. Lock pixels: Where there are pixels, you canâ€™t paint. You can move them.
  3. Lock position: You canâ€™t move things with the Move Tool. You can paint them.
  4. Artboards: Prevent auto-nesting into and out of Artboards.
  5. Lock everything: You canâ€™t paint or move anything.

These locks are different from the one at the bottom of the Layers panel. These lock the ability to move or paint a layer. The chain link at the bottom of the panel link layers together so them move together.

Opacity & Fill

Opacity is transparency. Lower it and the contents of the whole layer become translucent or transparent.

Fill mostly works exactly like the Opacity control. The major difference is that it doesnâ€™t affect effects. So, if you have Fill set to 0, the photo will disappear, but its Drop Shadow will show.

Bottom of the panel

Letâ€™s Practice

Letâ€™s use each one of these types of layers. Create a new document, then add guides on your canvas with View > New Guide Layout..

Use the guide below to build the layout as shown. Start by dragging each of the provided photos from the Finder into your Photoshop canvas.

Save this file as Appleseed, Johnny, #, Layers Practice.psd

Formative Activity

Letâ€™s build the file below to get the hang of creating and managing different types of layers.

Start by creating a letter-sized landscape document.

Weâ€™ll drag the photos into our canvas so they become Smart Objects. This allows for non-destructive resizing.

We need to create guides to line up all of our content in a structured layout. Go View > New Guide Layoutâ€¦

Weâ€™ll use the Free Transform command to resize photos to fit our grid. Make sure you import the provided title text. Itâ€™s an Illustrator document.

Use the vector rectangle tool to create a rectangle behind the four photos. We can use the fill controls in the Control Bar to choose a colour.

Next, weâ€™ll apply a stroke effect to the four smaller photos. To do this, go to the Fx menu at the bottom of the Layers panel and choose Stroke.

Add an 8pt white stroke to the photos. Weâ€™ll apply the effect to the layer group so it applies to all the layers inside it.

To fill your frame with text, you can go to the Type menu: Type > Paste Lorem Ipsum. You can change the colour of your type from the colour control in the Control Bar. Target your type tool and the type layer to do so.

Lastly, we can make our title graphic stand out a bit more with Layer Effects. We can use a Colour Overlay and an Outer Glow or a Drop Shadow.

There we go. Weâ€™ve successfully used the Layers Panel to create a layout in Photoshop in a non-destructive workflow.

Assessment

This is a formative assignment. That means that you'll be learning and practicing new software skills. This assignment contributes to your final grade in the course. This work will be graded as either:

Complete Incomplete

If needed, I will provide written feedback on your performance.

Submission Instructions

Once you've completed your work, make sure that your Photoshop document has no unexpected file dependancies. Your Layers Panel should not include any linked smart objects. Linked Smart Objects have a chain link icon on their layer in the Layers Panel.

If you've used fonts, they should only be from Adobe Fonts. You don't need to submit any fonts in that case.

Name your file Last name, First name, Group NÂº, Layers.psd. so,

Appleseed-Johnny-#-Layers.psd.zip

Right-click, then choose Compress... to create a zip file for submission.

Failure to submit your files as directed will incur a proportional loss of points. If your file/folder is not named with your name, you will earn a zero. Why?
